text: The reality with PMs is that within each of these buckets, there's so many skills and then you can feel overwhelmed, so my advice is really just start skill by skill. What I did specifically is I joined Slack, I was in ICPM. When you join a new company, especially if you're earlier in the mid-career, you really want to get good at things like execution, IQ skills, execution, product sense, strategy.
speaker: Jules Walter
context: Lenny asks Jules about the most important skills to develop as a PM to advance in one's career. Jules divides PM skills into two categories: IQ skills (hard skills like execution, product sense, strategy) and EQ skills (soft skills like communication, leadership). He emphasizes that rather than trying to improve everything at once, PMs should focus on developing one skill at a time, starting with the foundational IQ skills early in their career.
text_ko: PM(프로덕트 매니저)로서의 현실은 각 분야마다 정말 많은 스킬이 있어서 가끔은 압도당할 수 있어요. 그래서 제 조언은 정말 하나씩 스킬을 쌓아가는 거예요. 제가 구체적으로 했던 것은 Slack에 가입하고 ICPM에 참여한 거예요. 새로운 회사에 들어가면, 특히 경력이 중반쯤인 경우에는 실행(execution), IQ 스킬, 프로덕트 감각(product sense), 전략(strategy) 같은 것들을 잘 익히는 게 정말 중요해요.
text_zh: 做PM(产品经理)的现实情况是，每个领域里都有太多技能要掌握，很容易让人觉得压力山大。我的建议就是一个技能一个技能地来，别想着一口吃成胖子。我当时的做法是加入了Slack，还有ICPM这些社区。当你进入一家新公司，特别是如果你还处在职业发展的中期阶段，你真的需要在执行力、智商技能(IQ skills)、执行、产品感觉(product sense)、战略这些方面变得更强。
text_es: La realidad con los PMs es que dentro de cada una de estas categorías, hay tantas habilidades que te puedes sentir abrumado, entonces mi consejo es realmente empezar habilidad por habilidad. Lo que hice específicamente fue unirme a Slack, estaba en ICPM. Cuando te unes a una empresa nueva, especialmente si estás en la etapa intermedia de tu carrera, realmente quieres volverte bueno en cosas como ejecución, habilidades de IQ, ejecución, intuición de producto (product sense), estrategia.
key_sentence: Start skill by skill to avoid feeling overwhelmed in your mid-career.

text: When people tell me, 'Hey, I'm going to a interview at this company.' First question I ask is, 'How many mock interviews have you done?' And the answer typically is zero. It's, 'Oh, I read a bunch of stuff. I practiced in my head.' But I'm like, 'How many actual mock interviews have you done?' And I would recommend people to do dozens of those mock interviews.
speaker: Jules Walter
context: Lenny asks Jules about building interview skills, which Jules identifies as a crucial but overlooked PM skill. Jules explains that getting into great companies like Slack is essential for career growth, but most people prepare poorly for interviews. He emphasizes that reading about interviews isn't enough - candidates need to practice actual mock interviews repeatedly to build this critical skill that opens doors to better opportunities.
text_ko: 사람들이 “나 이 회사 면접 보러 가요”라고 하면 제가 제일 먼저 묻는 게 “모의 면접(mock interviews)을 몇 번이나 해봤어요?”예요. 보통 대답은 한 번도 안 했다고 해요. “아, 자료는 많이 읽었고 머릿속으로 연습했어요”라고들 하는데, 저는 “진짜로 모의 면접(mock interviews)을 몇 번이나 해봤어요?”라고 다시 물어봐요. 저는 사람들에게 그런 모의 면접을 수십 번은 해보라고 권해요.
text_zh: 有人跟我说，"嘿，我要去某某公司面试了。"我第一个问题就是，"你做过几次模拟面试(mock interview)？"答案基本上都是零。他们会说，"哦，我看了好多资料，在脑子里练了练。"但我就问，"你到底做过几次真正的模拟面试？"我建议大家至少要做几十次模拟面试才行。
text_es: Cuando la gente me dice, 'Oye, tengo una entrevista en esta empresa.' La primera pregunta que les hago es, '¿Cuántas entrevistas simuladas has hecho?' Y la respuesta típicamente es cero. Es como, 'Ah, me leí un montón de cosas. Practiqué mentalmente.' Pero yo les digo, '¿Cuántas entrevistas simuladas de verdad has hecho?' Y yo les recomendaría a la gente hacer docenas de esas entrevistas simuladas.
key_sentence: Dozens of mock interviews are essential for interview preparation.

text: What I do specifically is when I'm trying to learn something new, I try to think about what is an outcome that I could drive. And if I drive this outcome, it will be proof that I'm better at this thing. If we go back to this story of when I joined Slack, I didn't know anything, literally anything about growth. And I was telling myself, 'I hope they don't fire me.' But then the outcome I wanted is, within six months, I wanted to ship enough experiments that were successful, that drove activation by, let's say, X percent.
speaker: Jules Walter
context: Lenny asks Jules about his most effective methods for building PM skills. Jules explains his approach of creating forcing functions - setting concrete, measurable outcomes as proof of skill development. He uses his experience joining Slack as their first growth PM as an example, where despite knowing nothing about growth, he committed to driving specific activation improvements within six months, which forced him to rapidly learn the necessary skills.
text_ko: 제가 구체적으로 하는 건, 새로운 걸 배우려고 할 때 어떤 성과를 만들어낼 수 있을지 먼저 생각하는 거예요. 그 성과를 만들어내면 그게 제가 그걸 더 잘하게 됐다는 증거가 되니까요. 슬랙에 합류했을 때 얘기로 돌아가면, 저는 진짜로 '그로스(growth)'에 대해 하나도 몰랐어요. 그래서 혼자 '제발 날 해고하지 않길'이라고 생각하고 있었죠. 그런데 제가 바랐던 결과는 6개월 안에 성공적인 실험(experiments)을 충분히 많이 진행해서 활성화(activation)를, 예를 들어 X%만큼 올리는 거였어요.
text_zh: 我的具体做法是，当我想学新东西的时候，我会想"我能达成什么结果？如果我真的做到了，那就证明我在这方面确实有进步了。"回到我刚加入Slack那会儿，我对增长(growth)真的是一窍不通，什么都不懂。当时心里想的就是"千万别被炒鱿鱼啊。"但是我给自己定了个目标：六个月内，我要做足够多的成功实验，把激活率(activation)提升个X个百分点。
text_es: Lo que hago específicamente es que cuando trato de aprender algo nuevo, me pongo a pensar: ¿qué resultado puedo lograr? Y si logro este resultado, va a ser la prueba de que ya domino mejor esta cosa. Si volvemos a la historia de cuando entré a Slack, no sabía nada, literalmente nada sobre growth. Y me decía a mí mismo: "Ojalá no me despidan." Pero entonces el resultado que quería era que en seis meses, quería lanzar suficientes experimentos exitosos que aumentaran la activación en, digamos, X por ciento.
key_sentence: Driving an outcome proves that I'm better at new skills.

text: What I do then is I start asking questions like, 'Okay, I'm trying to drive activation for Slack. What are some frameworks that I should use to drive activation? What are best practices? What are examples?' I have a sense of the kind of question that, if I were to answer them, I'd be able to drive the outcome. And then what I do is I read a little bit, not a lot about the topic, just to make sure I'm asking the right question. Then I refine my questions and then I find the best people in the field and I just go talk to them.
speaker: Jules Walter
context: Jules continues explaining his systematic approach to learning new PM skills. After setting a concrete outcome goal, he works backwards by identifying the key questions he needs to answer. Rather than extensive reading, he does minimal research to formulate better questions, then seeks out experts in the field to learn directly from them. This approach helped him rapidly master growth principles at Slack by connecting with top practitioners like Bangaly Kaba from Facebook.
vocabulary_highlights: find the best people in the field
text_ko: 그럼 저는 이렇게 질문을 던지기 시작해요. “음, 지금 슬랙(Slack)의 활성화(activation)를 이끌어내려고 하는데, 활성화를 이끌어내기 위해 어떤 프레임워크(frameworks)를 써야 할까? 베스트 프랙티스(best practices)는 뭐고, 사례(examples)는 어떤 게 있을까?” 이런 질문들에 답할 수 있다면 원하는 결과를 만들 수 있겠다는 감이 들어요. 그다음 관련 주제에 대해 조금 읽어보긴 하는데, 많이 읽지는 않고요—질문이 제대로 됐는지 확인할 정도만요. 그런 다음 질문을 다듬고, 해당 분야에서 제일 잘 아는 사람들을 찾아가서 그냥 만나서 이야기해요.
text_zh: 然后我就开始问一些问题，比如"好，我想提高Slack的用户激活率(activation)，我应该用什么框架来提升激活率？有什么最佳实践？有哪些案例可以参考？"我心里大概知道哪些问题如果能回答清楚的话，就能达到我想要的结果。接下来我会稍微读点相关资料，不用太多，主要是确保我问的问题是对的。然后我会完善一下我的问题，找到这个领域最牛的那些人，直接去跟他们聊。
text_es: Lo que hago entonces es empezar a hacer preguntas como: "Bueno, estoy tratando de impulsar la activación para Slack. ¿Qué metodologías debería usar para impulsar la activación? ¿Cuáles son las mejores prácticas? ¿Qué ejemplos hay?" Tengo una idea del tipo de pregunta que, si las pudiera responder, lograría el resultado que busco. Entonces lo que hago es leer un poquito sobre el tema, no mucho, solo para asegurarme de que estoy haciendo las preguntas correctas. Después refino mis preguntas y luego encuentro a los mejores expertos en el área y simplemente voy y hablo con ellos.
key_sentence: Refine my questions to find the best people in the field.

text: What I've seen is the path that we just talked about, join a startup and then from there go into different companies. And then the other path that is typical is being at a company and then switching product management, especially if you develop domain expertise and there's a need for a PM. So, that's even more frequent. Of course there's also acquisitions that sort of thing, but making that initial transition is really hard.
speaker: Jules Walter
context: Lenny asks Jules about his path into product management, specifically noting that Jules joined a startup as one of their first PMs. Jules explains that breaking into product management is extremely difficult and there isn't a set path. He identifies two main routes: joining a startup where you can take on PM responsibilities, or transitioning internally at an existing company where you've developed relevant domain expertise.
text_ko: 제가 본 바로는, 우리가 방금 이야기한 경로가 있어요. 스타트업에 들어가서 거기서 다른 회사로 가는 거죠. 그리고 또 하나의 일반적인 경로는 한 회사에서 일하다가 제품 관리(Product Management)로 전환하는 건데, 특히 특정 분야에 대한 전문성이 생기고 PM이 필요할 때 자주 일어나요. 물론 인수합병 같은 경우도 있지만, 그 초기 전환이 정말 어렵죠.
text_zh: 我看到的情况是，刚才咱们说的那条路，就是先加入初创公司，然后再跳到其他公司。另外还有一条比较常见的路子，就是在一个公司待着，然后转做产品经理，特别是如果你在某个领域有专业经验，公司又需要PM的话。这种情况其实更多见。当然了，也有通过收购这种方式的，但最开始那个转型真的挺难的。
text_es: Lo que he visto es el camino del que acabamos de hablar, meterte en una startup y de ahí saltar a diferentes empresas. Y luego está el otro camino que es típico: estar en una empresa y después cambiar a product management (gestión de producto), sobre todo si desarrollas expertise en el sector y hay necesidad de un PM. Eso es incluso más común. Por supuesto también están las adquisiciones y ese tipo de cosas, pero hacer esa transición inicial es realmente difícil.
key_sentence: The initial transition to product management is really hard without domain expertise.

text: But externally, I'm like, 'Hey, thank you,' and I mean it. I think that's the key that most people don't focus on. And if you get more feedback, then you'll just get better at the things.
speaker: Jules Walter
context: At the beginning of the episode, Jules is explaining his approach to receiving feedback. He describes how even when feedback is difficult to hear internally (his 'heart might be melting'), he always responds with genuine gratitude externally. This creates a reputation for being receptive to feedback, which encourages people to continue providing honest input that helps him improve his skills over time.
text_ko: 그래도 겉으로는 "고마워요"라고 말하고, 진심이에요. 그게 대부분 사람들이 잘 신경 쓰지 않는 핵심이라고 생각해요. 피드백을 더 받으면 그만큼 더 잘하게 돼요.
text_zh: 但是在外表上，我会说"嘿，谢谢你"，而且我是真心的。我觉得这就是关键点，大多数人都没有注意到这一点。如果你能得到更多反馈，你在这些事情上就会做得更好。
text_es: Pero por fuera, yo digo "Oye, muchas gracias" y lo digo en serio. Creo que esa es la clave en la que la mayoría de la gente no se enfoca. Y si recibes más retroalimentación (feedback), pues simplemente vas a mejorar en las cosas.
key_sentence: Focus on getting more feedback to improve externally.
